newsitem.title: FINLAND: Finland Bank cuts key rate as ERM link nears.
newsitem.headline: Finland Bank cuts key rate as ERM link nears.

text.p: The Bank of Finland on Wednesday shaved 10 basis points off its key tender rate, a move which analysts said clearly demonstrated that Finland plans to link its currency, the markka, to Europe's stability mechanism.

Citing low inflation, interest rate convergence and confidence in the markka, the Bank trimmed its key tender rate to three percent, bringing it down by three full percentage points in a year, to equal the German Bundesbank's repo rate.

But the cut made no impression on foreign exchange markets, and analysts could see only one true motive -- to inhibit any further strengthening of the markka ahead of a widely expected link to Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism.

"We are in the waiting room, we are leaving the regime of a completely freely floating exchange rate behind and we are about to link to ERM," said Risto Murto, chief economist at brokerage Selin Finance.

The bank acted hours after Finance Minister Sauli Niinisto said it seemed likely that belonging to ERM was an unconditional criterion for joining the third stage of a single currency -- although his comments had made no impression on the markka.
"The general opinion ... is that ERM is a system which one must join," Niinisto told a briefing for business executives and reporters.
"It seems that belonging to ERM is unconditional," he said. "It has become very probable that belonging to the Exchange Rate Mechanism will be an absolute criterion."

He repeated that the issue of linking the markka to the ERM "will be decided this autumn", adding that the government had taken a slight risk in not joining ERM in time to have been in the system for the required two years.

Finland has long stated that it intends to be among the first to join Economic and Monetary Union, due to start in 1999; but some officials have argued that the currency has been stable enough outside ERM and may not need a formal link.

"I think the Bank of Finland (is) preparing the ERM linking and that's their role in this play," said Teijo Rantatupa, OKOBANK Treasury Economist; adding that he felt Wednesday's cut alone would not be enough to weaken the markka.

The markka, which remained steady after Wednesday's move, has for months been on a rising trend against the German mark -- contrary to Finland's competitive interest which would aim, if a peg were made, for this to be as the currency is weak.
Asked if he felt the cut would invite speculation about a markka-ERM link this weekend or soon, Rantatupa said the timing was irrelevant as markets were already expecting a link.
"It doesn't matter when it takes place -- the market has discounted it for two to three weeks now. It doesn't matter when it happens," he said.
Selin's Murto said the logic of braking the markka's rise meant a further independent Finnish key rate cut could not be ruled out.
"With this logic ... it is not out of the question that the Finnish tender rate could, temporarily, go below the German repo rate," he said.
